translated: The Buddha Speaks the MahÄyÄna Ä€rya Maá¹…gala DhÄraá¹‡Ä« SÅ«tra for Protecting the World
NÄlandÄ Temple in Magadha, Central India
Tripiá¹­aka Master, Dharma Master, Monk, Subject FÇtiÄn, Bestowed with Purple Robes
Translated by Imperial Decree Thus have I heard.
At one time the World-Honored One
was in the great thorn forest of KauÅ›ÄmbÄ«,
together with a great assembly of four hundred and fifty bhiká¹£us,
all of whom were well-known great arhats,
as well as bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
The Dharma assemblies of all buddhas came and gathered,
respectfully surrounding him to listen to the Buddha speak the Dharma.
At that time, in the assembly there was an elder named Wonderful Moon,
who resided in the great city of KauÅ›ÄmbÄ«.
This elder had great wisdom and skillful means,
with many sons, daughters, male and female servants, and a complete retinue.
They all possessed good roots and gave rise to a great wholesome mind.
At that time, the elder Wonderful Moon
went to see the World-Honored One. Having arrived at the Buddha's place,
he respectfully joined his palms and bowed at the Buddha's feet.
He then circumambulated [the Buddha] a hundred thousand times.
Having sat down to one side with composure,
the elder Sudharmottara addressed the Buddha, saying,
World-Honored One, on this day,
I wish to ask the TathÄgata, the Worthy of Offerings, the Perfectly Enlightened One,
that there are matters in my mind that I doubt.
I only wish that the World-Honored One, with immeasurable great kindness, would
explain the Dharma for me and resolve my doubts.
At that time, the World-Honored ÅšÄkyamuni
told the elder Sudharmottara,
I now allow you to ask whatever matters you doubt in your mind.
You should not keep your doubts in your own mind.
When the elder Sudharmottara heard the Buddha's words,
he again addressed the Buddha, saying, World-Honored One,
if good men and good women
suffer from poverty,
how can they avoid the suffering of poverty?
Those who are often ill,
How can one avoid suffering from illness?
At that time, the World-Honored One, who is endowed with all knowledge,
said to the elder Sudatta:
Why do you now only think of the poor,
and with a doubting mind ask this question?
The elder Sudatta said to the World-Honored One:
I am now poor, World-Honored One, I am now poor, Well-Gone One.
I have many relatives, sons, daughters, servants, and my home is full.
Please tell me now.
World-Honored One, according to my question, please explain the Dharma for me.
For poor beings, by what means can they be freed from poverty and suffering?
For those with many illnesses, by what means can they be free from the afflictions of illness?
As for the wealth and treasures needed for daily life, such as grain and wheat,
how can one's storehouses be filled?
How can one see what is delightful?
Gold, silver, maá¹‡i jewels, pearls, lapis lazuli,
conch shells, jade, coral, agate,
and vajra treasures, filling one's storehouses to overflowing.
May my giving be inexhaustible.
How can I obtain a household and relatives,
sons, daughters, and those of high status and self-mastery?
The elder Sumukha spoke these words to the World-Honored One.
At that time,
the Buddha again told the elder Sumukha:
In the past, countless eons ago,
in that world, there was a Buddha who appeared in the world.

His name was VajrapÄá¹‡i Ocean Great Sound TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Person, Tamer, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One.
I will, in the presence of that World-Honored One,
hear the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« called Auspicious World-Holder.
Having heard this Dharma, I will always uphold, recite, and sincerely make offerings to it.
And I will also widely proclaim this dhÄraá¹‡Ä« for others.
Good man, I will now tell you this dhÄraá¹‡Ä« to protect you.
Humans will not be able to harm you, and non-humans will also not be able to harm you.
Yakshas cannot harm them. Raksasas cannot harm them.
Pretas cannot harm them. Putas cannot harm them.
Pishachas cannot harm them.ğŸ”½Ghandharvas cannot harm them.ğŸ”½Utsadas cannot harm them. Pukkasa cannot harm them.
Khattiya pukkasa cannot harm them.ğŸ”½Those who eat feces cannot harm them.
Those who eat urine cannot harm them.
Those who eat various pure and impure things also cannot harm them.
Good man, this auspicious DhÄraá¹‡Ä« for Upholding the World,
If there are good men and good women,
Who obtain this DhÄraá¹‡Ä« SÅ«tra in their own homes,
Or respectfully make offerings to it in their hands,
Or contemplate this Dharma,
Or obtain the opportunity to hear this Dharma,
They should then uphold, recite, and make offerings to it.
Or extensively explain the meaning for others.
This good man or good woman,
Will always be protected and guarded, peaceful, happy, and joyful day and night.
With abundant food and drink, they will obtain great blessings and virtues.
This auspicious DhÄraá¹‡Ä« SÅ«tra for Upholding the World,
If one is able to make offerings to it with utmost sincerity,
It is the same as making offerings to all TathÄgatas, Arhats, and Samyaksaá¹ƒbuddhas of the past, present, and future.
If one is able to rely on the Dharma and recite this DhÄraá¹‡Ä« four times every midnight,
This person will then be protected and guarded by the devas, who will rejoice and love him.
The devas will also personally descend for this person,
And rain down the most delicious and wonderful food and drink.
The multitudes of devas will give rise to joy in their hearts towards all TathÄgatas.
They will give rise to joy in their hearts towards the Buddha's teachings.
They will give rise to joy in their hearts towards the Buddha's signless wisdom.
They will give rise to joy in their hearts towards the harmonious assembly.
They will give rise to joy in their hearts towards the Dharma teachers.
The Buddha further said to the Elder Wonderful Moon:
I will now, for your sake and for all sentient beings in the future,
Cause them to obtain vast benefits and happiness.
